awd_titl_txt: Meta-Surfaces for Far-Field Radiation Control and Near-Field Radiation Enhancement
awd_abstract_narration:
Radiation is an important energy transfer process that has wide applications in energy harvesting, production, and utilization. Radiation energy transfer can be accomplished by far-field radiation, where radiative surfaces are separated by a distance longer than the radiation wavelength (typically several to tens of micrometers) and near-field radiation, in which the surfaces are separated by a distance shorter than the radiation wavelength. In this project, engineered surfaces with specifically designed very small (microscale) patterns, called meta-surfaces, are studied to achieve specific far-field radiation properties and to enhance near-field radiation for applications such as thermal-photovoltaics in solar energy harvesting. The project aims to generate a wealth of scientific and engineering knowledge to advance the fundamentals and engineering of radiation energy transfer. It can also be applied to other fields of science and engineering, including high resolution imaging, sensing, and infrared radiation sources. In addition, the project provides education and training to the next generation scientists and engineers, broadens participation of underrepresented groups, and increases public awareness of radiation science and technology.

This project designs novel meta-surfaces that are advantages for the desired radiation properties and transfer processes. Specifically, meta-surfaces capable of enhancing the magnetic radiation field in addition to the electrical radiation field are studied. This approach provides the design space for manipulating both electric and magnetic properties to achieve desired far- and near-field performances, while using relatively simple two-dimensional meta-surface structures. Advanced experimental techniques are used in this project, including near-field radiation measurements with surface separation distances of tens of nanometers, FTIR (Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy) coupled with near-field scanning optical microscopy, FTIR near-field emission microscopy, and far-field FTIR spectroscopy. These studies provide a complete micro-to-macro spectroscopic picture of the designed meta-surfaces to validate the design theories, therefore, to advance far- and near-field radiation research and facilitate their applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project is to investigate far-field radiation control and near-field radiation enhancement, two fundamentally related processes with a wide range of applications for energy conversion and energy utilization, through the design and use of meta-surfaces.

Meta-materials or meta-surfaces are artificially engineered materials or surface structures that exhibit unique and often superior properties. We successfully designed easy-to-fabricate meta-surfaces for far field radiation control in infrared wavelengths, i.e., to achieve certain radiative properties at these wavelengths useful for various thermal engineering applications, and then fabricated and demonstrated these meta-surfaces for greatly enhanced radiation absorption/emission properties. We also fabricated and demonstrated large-scale chiral meta-surfaces to achieve desired chiral radiation properties useful for radiation detection. 

It has been known that near-field radiation – radiation between two closely spaced surfaces, can be greatly enhanced compared with normal far field radiation. We investigated fundamental near-field radiative transfer processes in polar materials and hyperbolic materials and revealed the fundamentally different mechanisms underlying the two types of materials for near-field radiative transfer enhancement. We developed an experimental apparatus to investigate near-field radiative transfer across a gap as small as 7 nm. We experimentally demonstrated near-field radiative transfer is more than four orders of magnitude greater than that of black-body radiation at such small gaps.

Additionally, we demonstrated, for the first time, that radiative transfer inside a material can be of the same order of conduction by phonons, enabled by the hyperbolic phonon polaritons in hyperbolic materials. We showed that the radiative transport in hBN, a type of hyperbolic material, is more than six orders of magnitude greater than that of blackbody. This opened a new heat transfer channel for a wide range of applications including thermal management in advanced photonic and electronic devices and more efficient energy conversion in the processes such as thermophotovoltaic.

Overall, the project has advanced the studies on radiative transfer that has enormous applications in the efficient use of energy and efficient energy conversion. Results of the studies have been broadly disseminated through publications in journals, presentations at conferences, and websites. The project also provided trainings to a large number of graduate and undergraduate students in the area of radiative heat transfer, including theoretical studies, computation design and optimization, micro-fabrication and characterization, and development of new experimental capabilities, and thus contributed to the human resource development in thermal science and engineering.
